description: {"blocks":[{"key":"4saa8","text":"Sleep apnea is a common disorder in humans and consists of recurrent episodes of cessation of breathing or decrease in airflow during sleep. Sleep apneas can be classified as central (CSA) or obstructive (OSA), based on their origin. CSA results from impairments of the inspiratory drive generated by the brainstem with a consequent interruption of diaphragm muscle effort, while OSA occurs due to upper airway obstruction during inspiration with a continued or increased respiratory effort. Mice are valuable tools to expedite the comprehension of the pathophysiology and genetics of sleep apneas and the development of targeted therapies to contrast sleep-disordered breathing and its adverse consequences on health. Therefore, we provide a method for distinguishing between CSA-like and OSA-like events during sleep in mice by simultaneously recording sleep states, breathing pattern, and diaphragm electromyographic activity inside a whole-body plethysmograph.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c4bae","text":"We applied this technique in adult C57BL/6J wild-type mice and in a mouse model of Down syndrome (PMID: 34509609).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Overview
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"8s245","text":"Figure 1 summarizes the chronological steps of the protocol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3jhsg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1pv21","text":"Figure 1. Overview of the protocol","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":34}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f5t4v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e2410","text":"The experimental protocol involves the crafting (Day -1) and the surgical implantation (Day 0) of the electrodes for the recording of electroencephalogram (EEG), nuchal muscle electromyogram (nEMG), and diaphragm electromyogram (DIA). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e1gkr","text":"After an appropriate period of full post-operatory recovery (Day 5), mice underwent a 7-hour session inside a whole-body plethysmograph to simultaneously record EEG, nEMG, DIA, and ventilation (VENT). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7n9cr","text":"In the analysis phase, EEG and nEMG signals are used for the sleep scoring, while VENT and DIA signals are employed for the classification of sleep apneas.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 1: Crafting of electrodes
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"eai6d","text":"Gently remove 2-3 mm of the coating from both ends of each wire.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 1: Crafting of electrodes
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"8rvak","text":"Solder one end of each wire to a stainless-steel screw; we suggest using screws with a length of 2.4 mm and a diameter of 1.2 mm.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 1: Crafting of electrodes
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"829s5","text":"Solder the uninsulated remaining end of each wire to a connector equipped with two terminal pins (one wire per pin); we suggest using connectors about 0.5 cm wide and 0.3 cm high.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 1: Crafting of electrodes
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"e60hu","text":"b)\tPreparation of nEMG electrode (Figures 2B-3B and Video 2)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":60}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 1: Crafting of electrodes
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"c46es","text":"Cut a pair of 4-cm long multi-stranded stainless-steel wires coated with an insulating sheath.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 1: Crafting of electrodes
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4i5al","text":"Remove 2-3 mm of the coating from one end of each wire and at 1.5 cm from it.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 1: Crafting of electrodes
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"10qv7","text":"Solder the uninsulated end of the wire to a connector equipped with two terminal pins (one wire per pin).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 1: Crafting of electrodes
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"d8v3d","text":"c)\tPreparation of DIA electrode (Figures 2C-3C and Video 3)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":59}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 1: Crafting of electrodes
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"bo6ra","text":"Cut a pair of 12-cm long multi-stranded stainless-steel wires coated with an insulating sheath.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 1: Crafting of electrodes
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"42b6j","text":"Bend each wire into a hairpin-like shape.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 1: Crafting of electrodes
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"7mlj5","text":"Twist the wire on itself until it reaches a final length of 6 cm, ensuring the hairpin bend is enlarged and shaped as a circle with about 2 mm in diameter.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 1: Crafting of electrodes
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"drju1","text":"Gently melt the coating along the wire using a hot air flux to stabilize the shape of the electrode.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 1: Crafting of electrodes
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"2k65","text":"Remove 2-3 mm of the coating from the free end of each wire and the circular hairpin bend.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 1: Crafting of electrodes
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"fkrm","text":"Solder the uninsulated end of each wire to a connector equipped with two terminal pins (one wire per pin).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 1: Crafting of electrodes
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"drlb0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"episp","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"l4b8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"629q2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ev52k","text":"Critical points:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"333jb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"asgp4","text":"For a longer and more stable duration of the soldering, we suggest using a commercial catalyst (e.g., zinc chloride-based solution).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5esga","text":"To safeguard the electrodes from potential damage during the removal of the coating, we recommend performing this procedure under a surgical microscope (this step is strongly recommended for the DIA electrode).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6r83g","text":"To increase electrode longevity, we suggest applying an acrylic paste to cover the soldering.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dv03c","text":"For validation of electrode functionality, we recommend testing the electrical conductance of the uninsulated portions using a suitable tool (e.g., a multimeter tester) before using it. We suggest measuring the electrical resistance using a threshold of 20,000 ohms.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":4,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"bvdet","text":"Tip:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"edipc","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"203r2","text":"The dimensions of all electrodes can be adapted to the animal’s size (e.g., shorter wires may be required for younger and smaller mice).","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{},"guid":"475219D360CB4F71875108C680B6D4C1"}}}}

steps.section: Step 2: Sterilization of surgical materials
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"6uavt","text":"Surgery is performed under aseptic conditions; therefore, surgical instruments (forceps, tweezers, scissors with a curved tip, mosquito clamps, microsurgical scissors, periosteum remover, and needle holder) must be sterilized by an autoclave cycle at   for  . Alternatively, they can be disinfected with specific solutions (e.g., 0.35% peracetic acid solutions).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":251,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":257,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"121","unit":10}},"1":{"type":"duration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"duration":900,"guid":"","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null}}}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"a8jb","text":"The procedure is performed under aseptic conditions with the mouse anesthetized (isoflurane 2-2.5% in pure oxygen). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"2vl97","text":"Analgesic and antibiotic therapy are administered subcutaneously at the beginning and at the end of the surgery, respectively. During the entire duration of the surgery, the mouse is placed over a thermoregulated heating pad to prevent hypothermia.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5j8g4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"308mm","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3qe0m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5mrb4","text":"d)\tAnesthesia and surgical field disinfection","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":45}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":14}],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":15,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":15,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"2a46n","text":"Timing: about  ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"duration":4500,"guid":"","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"duration"}},"guid":"EEDCE78D4A3911EFB1980A58A9FEAC02"}}}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"56ge1","text":"Place the mouse in a closed chamber to induce the anesthesia.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"31ocf","text":"Place the mouse on the surgical table, ensuring that its nose and mouth are located within the anesthesia tube.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"24ps0","text":"Shave the mouse in the subcostal area (under the last rib) and the skin above the head between the ears (Figure 4).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"ci1h","text":"Disinfect the shaved surgical fields with an iodine solution.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4risi","text":"FIGURE 4 ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"j87b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3iuoa","text":"Figure 4. Surgical fields","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ongc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5u8um","text":"Photographs of the surgical fields after shaving showing the subcostal area (under the last rib, panel A) and the skin above the head between the ears (panel B).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"95viq","text":"e)\tDIA electrode implantation","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":29}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"3dq5i","text":"Place the mouse on an inclined plane with the head at a lower level than the rest of the body in order to obtain a better exposure of the surgical field.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"1nj6k","text":"Use scissors to make a 0.5-cm vertical skin incision over the skull between the ears (Figure 5A and Video 4).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"73hvf","text":"Make a second 0.5-cm vertical skin incision on the flank just below the last rib (Figure 5B and Video 4).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"8efeh","text":"Using surgical scissors with curved tips, create a subcutaneous tunnel connecting the two incisions (Video 5).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"a6qer","text":"Pass the DIA electrode subcutaneously from the head to the flank incision with the help of surgical forceps and a mosquito clamp. The electrode connector must remain on the animal’s head (Figure 6 and Video 5).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"d8dfb","text":"Place the mouse on the right flank.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"d55eh","text":"With the help of a surgical microscope, make a 0.5-cm horizontal cut in the abdominal muscle wall and the peritoneum under the last rib using microsurgical scissors (Figure 7A).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4nq97","text":"Identify the last rib attached to the sternum and the eighth intercostal space (i.e., the space between the two last ribs connected to the sternum) (Figure 7B).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"10dj0","text":"Position the DIA electrode in the correct position (Figure 8). Video 6 provides a detailed step-by-step guide for implanting the DIA electrode, illustrating the following process:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7hufn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"25pri","text":"I.\tPass a thin non-absorbable surgical thread through the eight intercostal space from outside to inside the abdominal cavity.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"58tcc","text":"II.\tBend the DIA electrode wires to adapt to the natural shape of the abdominal cavity of the mouse.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"brqh0","text":"III.    Pass the surgical thread through one of the circular hairpin bends of the DIA electrode.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"386nf","text":"IV.\tPass the surgical thread back through the same intercostal space in the peritoneal wall, this time proceeding from intrabdominal to external.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ba5tg","text":"V.\tCut the surgical thread, making sure to leave enough length to tie a knot.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3duvv","text":"VI.\tInsert the DIA electrode’s circular hairpin bend into the abdominal cavity.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5fech","text":"VII.   Pull the suture thread until the circular hairpin bend of the DIA electrode is in contact with the abdominal surface of the diaphragmatic muscle and tie a knot.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"9rut7","text":"Repeat the same procedure for the second DIA electrode’s circular hairpin bend, ensuring that the uninsulated circular portions of the electrode are positioned close to each other, but avoiding any contact between them (Video 6).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"dvge9","text":"Apply suture stitches to close the abdominal muscles around the electrode wires. A second series of stitches must be applied to the flank skin incision (Figure 9).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"e9pah","text":"f)\tEEG electrode implantation","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":29}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"613j3","text":"Place the mouse in a prone position on the stereotaxic apparatus to immobilize and expose the skull (Figure 10).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"3mdub","text":"Remove the periosteum from the skull and locally apply a drop of hydrogen peroxide (3% H2O2) to remove debris and better highlight the cranial sutures.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sub","offset":88,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":90,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"f59aj","text":"Identify bregma and lambda (i.e., the anterior and posterior crossing points of cranial sutures) (Figure 11A and B).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"d8qek","text":"Using a surgical microdrill, make four holes in the frontal and parietal bones 1 mm anterior and 1 mm lateral to both bregma and lambda (Figures 11C and 12A).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"6a6u","text":"Insert two stainless-steel screws in the holes on one side of the skull in contact with the dura mater for better anchoring and balancing the head cap structure to the skull (Figure 12B).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"cl49c","text":"Securely fasten the screws by turning them clockwise (usually one complete turn is sufficient; pay attention not to screw them excessively, which could damage the underlying cerebral cortex).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4h6f","text":"Insert the two screws of the EEG electrode in the two remaining contralateral holes of the skull in contact with the dura mater (Figure 12C).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4he4j","text":"Joint the screws and the connector of the EEG electrode to the skull bone using cement for dental use (e.g., biocompatible and atoxic resins composed of methacrylate and apatite).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4e94h","text":"g)\tImplantation of the nEMG electrode","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"9mv13","text":"Insert the nEMG electrode wires bilaterally in the nuchal muscles using a curved needle, ensuring that the uninsulated portion of the wire is located inside the muscle (Figure 13 A and B).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"3p59d","text":"Block the wires with a knot to keep them in position (Figure 13C).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 3: Surgical implantation of electrodes in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"34i28","text":"Incorporate the connectors of the EEG, nEMG, and DIA electrodes into a biocompatible acrylic paste for dental use on the mouse’s skull (Figure 14).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 4: Recording within a whole-body plethysmograph
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"2om46","text":"In this section, we describe how to prepare and perform the simultaneous recording of the animal’s behavioral states, ventilation, and diaphragmatic activity with whole-body plethysmography (WBP). The WBP apparatus consists of two chambers: one designed for housing the mouse, and a separate reference chamber. Each chamber is equipped with air inlet and outlet tubes. The mouse chamber includes temperature and humidity sensors, and a high-precision differential pressure transducer measures the pressure difference between the two chambers, allowing the detection of the animal’s breathing. The mouse body temperature should also be measured ideally.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"kn3j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5l4en","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c9c79","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"5lsst","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":8},{"key":1,"length":1,"offset":10}],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":11,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":11,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"9h6jc","text":"Timing:  - ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"duration":25200,"guid":"","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"duration"},"1":{"data":{"duration":28800,"guid":"","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"duration"}},"guid":"218E52584B0311EF85B70A58A9FEAC02"}}}}

steps.section: Step 4: Recording within a whole-body plethysmograph
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"3b0s3","text":"h)\tPreparation of the animal","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":28}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"h6uv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d4gv8","text":"Before the recording, slightly anesthetize (1–2 minutes under 1-2% isoflurane anesthesia) the mouse to plug a lightweight cable to the electrodes in the head structure for the acquisition of EEG, nEMG, and DIA signals.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 4: Recording within a whole-body plethysmograph
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"16dmh","text":"i)   Recording within the WBP chamber","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f8380","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"evqf8","text":"Insert the mouse into the WBP chamber (Figures 15 and 16). We suggest equipping the apparatus with a rotating electrical commutator to prevent the twisting of the recording cable (Figure 17).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 4: Recording within a whole-body plethysmograph
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"9bb22","text":"I.\tThe chamber must be continuously purged with a suitable gas mixture to prevent carbon dioxide build-up. The airflow rate should be adjusted according to the size of the plethysmography chamber. For example, our chambers have a 0.97-liter internal volume and are ventilated with breathable air from cylinders at a rate of 1.5 liters per minute.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6d8cj","text":"II.\tThe animal respiratory signal is measured as the differential pressure between the chamber containing the animal and a second reference chamber through a high-precision differential pressure transducer, corrected based on the temperature and humidity signals, and calibrated based on the data obtained with the procedure detailed at point 42. Mouse body temperature information should also be used to correct tidal volume estimates, if available.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dc6pp","text":"III.\tThe EEG, nEMG, and DIA signals are acquired via a lightweight electrical cable, amplified, filtered, digitalized, and stored together with the WBP differential pressure.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fc2nm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 4: Recording within a whole-body plethysmograph
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"e4cbr","text":"At the end of the session, after removing the mouse from the chamber, calibrate the WBP system by repeatedly injecting and withdrawing air into the mouse chamber with a calibrated micro-syringe while recordings of the differential pressure between WBP chambers are still running. We recommend sequentially injecting and withdrawing 10, 20, 30, 40, and 50 microliters of air at the anticipated mean breathing rate of the mouse. These data will be used to construct a calibration curve to convert WBP pressure deflection into air volumes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

points:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"el7vp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5qjp0","text":"Remember to measure the temperature and the humidity of the animal chamber, and ideally also the animal’s body temperature, as they are relevant to the analysis of the WBP signal(1).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dolr6","text":"Always verify the proper sealing of the WBP chamber to ensure the acquisition of a high-quality differential pressure signal.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9mk3s","text":"WBP chambers are generally employed for recordings lasting 6-8 hours; with longer continuous recordings, waste (feces, urine, wet food pellets) in the mouse chamber may impact on the mouse well-being and Hz.","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8grv1","text":"We sample the signals at the following rates: EEG, 128 Hz; nEMG, DIA, and WBP differential pressure, 2048 Hz. ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2vqc4","text":"In case of significant electrical artifacts due to alternating current (50 or 60 Hz, according to the country) in one of the differential signals, we suggest attempting an alternative derivation for the signal. For example, if a significant electrical artifact occurs in the differential signal between the two pins of the EEG electrode, consider acquiring a differential signal between one EEG electrode pin and one nEMG electrode pin as reference. Please, note that, while this new configuration may still permit accurate sleep scoring, it is not suitable for EEG power spectral analysis.","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"e4lm8","text":"To minimize mechanical artifacts in the WBP differential pressure signal caused by the opening and closing of doors, we recommend limiting the entrance and exit in the recording laboratory to the essential minimum.","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{},"guid":"A3A92FBABF414448B42EDB4EC248CB60"}}}}

steps.section: Step 5: Discrimination of wake-sleep states in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"eiqu5","text":"In this section, we describe how to discriminate the different behavioral states in mice based on the EEG and nEMG signal traces according to published criteria. A more detailed description with figures and a specific MATLAB script for wake-sleep state discrimination in mice can be found in Bastianini et al., 2014(2). We recommend scoring mouse sleep with a 4-second time resolution.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7mpvb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8o8h7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8vjc8","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bl4og","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":116,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":116,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"a5noo","text":"Timing: variable (expert investigators can score a 7-hour recording with a 4-second time resolution in about 1 hour)","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{},"guid":"A97277A262144832A1B9138EC8FA861E"}}}}

steps.section: Step 5: Discrimination of wake-sleep states in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"8escr","text":"j)\tPerform the sleep scoring of the entire recording by visual inspection of raw EEG and nEMG signals(2–4) with the following criteria:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":135}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dj7vd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d61rd","text":"Wakefulness (W) is assigned when the nEMG tone is high and variable, and the EEG is at a low voltage with possible δ (0.5 – 4 Hz) and θ (6 – 9 Hz) frequency components.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"absl7","text":"Non-rapid-eye movement sleep (NREMS) is scored when the nEMG tone is lower than in W, and the EEG is at a high voltage with prominent δ frequency components.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6lpfv","text":"Rapid-eye movement sleep (REMS) is defined in the presence of muscle atonia (flat nEMG) with occasional muscle twitches, and when the EEG is at a low voltage with predominant θ activity.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ais5","text":"Epochs with artifacts or borderline signals should be marked as “undetermined” and excluded from the successive analyses.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 5: Discrimination of wake-sleep states in mice
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"cfnv0","text":"FIGURE 18","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"82a0n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6agsp","text":"Figure 18. Discrimination of the wake-sleep states","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":50}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ihpf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f186m","text":"Example of raw electroencephalographic (EEG) and nuchal electromyographic (nEMG) data obtained during wakefulness (W), non-rapid-eye-movements sleep (NREMS), and rapid-eye-movements sleep (REMS) in mice in our laboratory.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 6: Sleep apnea detection and categorization into CSA and OSA
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"cmkgt","text":"In this section, we first describe how to detect sleep apnea from the WBP signal and then, how to categorize sleep apneas into CSA and OSA based on the joint evaluation of the WBP and DIA signals.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4l0v7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d2gpj","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ana3d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":140,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"3ti7k","text":"Timing: variable (depending on the number of apneas to be evaluated; the examination of a 7-hour WBP recording typically takes about 1 hour)","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{},"guid":"16B8A2A32FA0472BBE061BC0A6C22E4B"}}}}

steps.section: Step 6: Sleep apnea detection and categorization into CSA and OSA
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"esa6p","text":"k)    Sleep apnea detection","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":27}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 6: Sleep apnea detection and categorization into CSA and OSA
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"7cque","text":"Using commercially available or custom-made algorithms, calculate the ventilatory period (VP, i.e., the duration of each breath) on the raw WBP tracings, computed as the time period between two consecutive peaks of the WBP signals.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 6: Sleep apnea detection and categorization into CSA and OSA
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"fh8eu","text":"Calculate the mean VP value for each mouse in each sleep state (i.e., NREMS and REMS).","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 6: Sleep apnea detection and categorization into CSA and OSA
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"ed2hc","text":"Calculate the apnea threshold for each sleep state, setting it at either two times (2x criterion) or three times (3x criterion, which is the more conservative criterion used in our lab) the mean VP values defined for each mouse.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 6: Sleep apnea detection and categorization into CSA and OSA
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"u7is","text":"Using commercially available or custom-made algorithms, for each sleep state, detect all the breaths longer than the apnea threshold and discard false detections due to artifacts (e.g., due to high-amplitude mechanical pressure artifacts caused by the opening or closing of laboratory doors) by visual evaluation of the raw tracings.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 6: Sleep apnea detection and categorization into CSA and OSA
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"d5bn1","text":"Figure 19 shows a representative tracing of the WBP differential pressure signal recorded inside the WBP chamber in our laboratory.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4r3aq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"54dfp","text":"FIGURE 19","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2o3vq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"88tak","text":"Figure 19. Ventilatory period","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":29}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4s9es","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"codjr","text":"The figure shows a representative tracing of the whole-body plethysmography differential pressure signal (in red) recorded in mice in our laboratory. Grey segments identify the ventilatory period (VP, i.e., the duration of each breath) associated with an apnea (red bracket) and some normal breaths (green bracket). The time scale is one second.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"87igj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9cdak","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ct36e","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"50pq5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":5,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"ni08","text":"Tips:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"73tpj","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6n8bp","text":"We suggest confining the analysis of respiratory variables to stable periods of NREMS and REMS lasting at least 12 seconds. The analysis of respiratory variables during wakefulness is usually particularly problematic in terms of mechanical artifacts in the WBP pressure signal.","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"cfqre","text":"For a more conservative analysis of apneas, we suggest using the 3x criterion as the apnea threshold; for more details, please refer to Bastianini et al. 2019(5).","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{},"guid":"1FBFB9886F494337B43DF821ADE63B17"}}}}

steps.section: Step 6: Sleep apnea detection and categorization into CSA and OSA
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"9ovd2","text":"l)\tCategorization into CSA and OSA of each manually checked apnea episode","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":73}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 6: Sleep apnea detection and categorization into CSA and OSA
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"dcqc2","text":"Classify the apnea as CSA when the absence of activity in WBP is concomitant with the absence of activity in the DIA signal.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Step 6: Sleep apnea detection and categorization into CSA and OSA
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"44ro5","text":"Classify the apnea as OSA when the absence of activity in WBP is coupled to one or more activity bursts on the DIA signal (i.e., with a clear activation of the diaphragm).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
